column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=1. Introduction
#Text=The honey bee is one of the most important economic insects .

#Text=By providing the essential pollination services for crops and wild plants , honey bees play a vital role in the sustainable development of modern agricultural industries and the global ecosystem , and produce a wide range of benefits for human well-being .

#Text=There is now mounting evidence indicating that the honey bee colony numbers in Western Europe and the US are in decline , which results in a severe pollination crisis and threatens crop production .
#Text=Multiple factors have been proposed driving force behind the global honey bee colony losses , where colony-associated parasites and pathogens are specifically emphasized .
#Text=Among them , it is believed that Varroa destructor , an obligate ectoparasite of honey bees , is the most threatening to bee health .
#Text=V. destructor had been misclassified to be another honey bee Varroa parasite , V. jacobsoni Oudemans for decades until 2000 .

#Text=V. destructor originally parasitizes the Asian honey bees , Apis cerana , but successfully switched its host to the European honey bees , A. mellifera likely in the Far East in the first half of the last century .

#Text=The infestation of A. mellifera colonies by V. destructor was initially found in East and South Asia in the 1950s , and then spread to the rest of the world shortly after , excluding Australia .

#Text=Unlike in its original host , V. destructor has posed a deadly threat to the survival of the new host A. mellifera , which lacks the resistant mechanisms as seen in A. cerana , due to long-term coevolution .

#Text=There are at least seven haplotypes of V. destructor identified based on a 458 bp fragment of the mitochondrial CO-I gene , including Korea , Japan/Thailand , Nepal , Vietnam , China , China 2 , and Sri Lanka haplotypes , and much greater genetic variation among V. destructor ( 18 haplotypes ) has been revealed using the concatenated mtDNA sequences ( 2700 bp ) .
#Text=However , only two of them , the Korea haplotype and the Japan/Thailand haplotype , have been found to infest the new host A. mellifera .

#Text=Mites of Korea haplotype have globally spread on A. mellifera , while the Japan/Thailand haplotype has a more restricted distribution and only been reported in Japan , Thailand , and North and South America .
#Text=The life cycle of V. destructor can be divided into two phases , the phoretic phase and the reproductive phase .
#Text=In the phoretic phase , Varroa females parasitize honey bee adults , and are previously thought to feed on the host hemolymph , but recently found to consume the fat body .
#Text=Reproduction of Varroa mites only happens inside the sealed honey bee brood cells during the reproductive phase .
#Text=Drone brood cells are more attractive to mites compared to worker brood , but much less available in natural colonies , as they are reared only during swarming season .

#Text=The ability to reproduce on worker brood emerges as a critical adaption to the new host , remarkably facilitating the development of Varroa population and causing greater damage to A. mellifera colonies .
#Text=In fact , Varroa mites that infest A. mellifera colonies are able to reproduce as effectively on worker brood as on drone brood .
#Text=In contrast , V. destructor has been found to reproduce exclusively on the drone brood and remain sterile on the worker brood of the original host A. cerana .
#Text=This phenomenon is considered crucial for the tolerance of A. cerana towards V. destructor , and the balance of the host-parasite relationship .
#Text=The high susceptibility of immature workers to Varroa infestation has been proposed as another resistant mechanism .
#Text=However , more and more studies have raised different arguments on this issue .
#Text=By both direct observations of natural infestation and artificial inoculation , many studies showed that V. destructor are capable of reproducing on the worker brood of A. cerana .
#Text=It should be pointed out that the haplotypes of Varroa mites used in the above studies were different .

#Text=Interestingly , the mites that reproduced on A. cerana worker brood were either the Korea haplotype or the Japan/Thailand haplotype , which are found to infest A. mellifera ; while those that were considered sterile on the A. cerana worker brood were neither Korea haplotype nor Japan/Thailand haplotype .

#Text=On the other hand , Varroa mites derived from A. cerana colonies in southwestern China and northern Vietnam , which were both identified to be Vietnam haplotype , were almost infertile in the worker cells of local A. mellifera colonies after artificial inoculation .

#Text=These findings suggest that the genetic variation among Varroa mites themselves might determine their reproductive capability on worker brood hosts , and mites of different haplotypes show varying reproductive capability on the worker brood of the same honey bee species , but further studies are needed to confirm this .
